description:
Plasmodium chabaudi chabaudi is a species of malaria parasite that infects rodents, specifically mice and rats. It is a subspecies of Plasmodium chabaudi, which is a member of the Plasmodium genus, the causative agents of malaria in various animal hosts.

Plasmodium chabaudi chabaudi is a unicellular eukaryotic organism that has a complex life cycle, alternating between the vertebrate host (rodent) and the invertebrate host (mosquito of the genus Anopheles). In the vertebrate host, the parasite invades and replicates within the red blood cells, causing the characteristic symptoms of malaria, such as fever, chills, and anemia. The subspecies P. chabaudi chabaudi is often used as a model organism in malaria research, as it provides insights into the mechanisms of host-parasite interactions, immune responses, and the development of potential antimalarial drugs and vaccines.
